title: How Palantir shifted course to play key role in ICE deportations - The Washington Post
content:
For years, Alex Karp, Palantirâ€™s CEO, had declared the data management company to be [â€œinvolved in supporting progressive values,â€](https://www.businessinsider.com/palantir-wikileaks-apology-2011-2) saying he has [repeatedly â€œwalked awayâ€](https://www.cnbc.com/video/2022/06/29/palantirs-alex-karp-on-the-intersection-of-big-tech-and-politics.html) from contracts that targeted minorities or that he found otherwise unethical. Even as Palantir took on extensive data management contracts for the federal government, the company said it was not willing to allow its powerful tools to broadly track immigrants across America.

That commitment no longer holds. Palantirâ€™s software is helping U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement track undocumented immigrants and deport them faster, according to federal procurement filings and interviews with people who have knowledge of the project and who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive details. The software, Immigration OS, plays a key role in supporting the administrationâ€™s mass deportation campaign, which President Donald Trump has stepped up in recent days with such measures as [pausing immigration applications](https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/12/02/trump-immigration-applications-paused-19-countries/) from nationals of 19 countries.

Karp, formerly an outspoken Democrat who a decade ago said that he respected â€œnothingâ€ about Trump and that a deportation drive made â€œno sense,â€ has staunchly defended the presidentâ€™s immigration policies in his second term. Declaring Palantir to be â€œcompletely anti-woke,â€ he has repeatedly praised Trumpâ€™s ongoing crackdown on immigrants, thrusting the company into one of the countryâ€™s most contentious issues.

That shift in political alliances in no way signals a change in his core beliefs, Karp said in a statement to The Washington Post, portraying his commitment to controlling immigration as of a piece with his long-standing devotion to social justice.

Demonstrators block the entrance to Palantir's New York offices in July, chanting slogans such as â€œNo ICE, No Palantir!â€ (Lokman Vural Elibol/Anadolu/Getty Images)

â€œFor over two decades, I have implored our political elite to take seriously the truly progressive position on immigration: one of extreme skepticism. To no avail,â€ Karp said. â€œUnfettered immigration in Europe, where I lived for well over a decade, has been a disaster â€” depressing wages for the working class and resulting in mass social dislocation. I remain an economic progressive, isolated among self-proclaimed progressives that are anything but.â€

The changes at Palantir have been driven by multiple factors, according to five of the people familiar with the companyâ€™s project. Palantir executives saw Trumpâ€™s election to a second term as a mandate from voters for stricter border control, the people said, and, like many other companies, Palantir has changed some policies in response to executive orders targeting diversity in hiring and other issues. They added that [Karpâ€™s support of Israel](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/03/13/palantir-ceo-says-outspoken-pro-israel-views-led-employees-to-leave-.html) after the Oct. 7, 2023, Hamas attack has drawn him closer to Republican national security hawks.

![](https://subscribe.washingtonpost.com/static/my-post/images/topics/trump-tracker-180px.png)

**Follow** Trumpâ€™s second term

Palantirâ€™s federal contracting business has bloomed during the Trump administration. Its September tally of new federal contracts was $128 million, its largest monthly sum on record, according to [USASpending.gov](http://usaspending.gov/). The companyâ€™s stock price is up more than 120 percent this year, as it rides its contracting wave and the boom in companies that, like Palantir, are centered on the development and use of AI.

Palantir has long defied simple political characterization. For years, it has worked with administrations of both parties on projects other Silicon Valley firms shunned, such as the Pentagonâ€™s [Project Maven AI target identification system](https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2025/08/01/palantir-trump-defense-tech-ai-software/). But its support for ICE on a deportation crackdown punctuated by violent clashes and stiff court challenges has sparked debate among current and former employees over whether it runs afoul of the companyâ€™s values and endangers its bipartisan profile.

Seven months into the project, which was renewed in late September, some Palantir employees still harbor concerns about Immigration OS, according to two of the people familiar with the matter. They say some Palantir staff members have been discussing whether the contract should be discontinued if ICEâ€™s use of the technology veers into extrajudicial actions or violate the companyâ€™s civil liberties principles. It couldnâ€™t be determined whether the companyâ€™s senior executives are involved in those discussions. A Palantir spokeswoman declined to comment.

ICE and its parent department, the Department of Homeland Security, declined to answer questions about Immigration OS. DHS said in a statement that Palantir has been a contractor for 14 years, providing â€œsolutions for investigative case management and enforcement operationsâ€ to ICE. â€œDHS looks holistically at technology and data solutions that can meet operational and mission demands,â€ it said.

ICE awarded Palantir a $30 million contract on April 11 to build an â€œImmigration Lifecycle Operating System,â€ or Immigration OS for short. Its aim, according to procurement filings by the agency, is to facilitate the â€œselection and apprehension operations of illegal aliensâ€ based on ICE priorities, minimize â€œtime and resource expenditureâ€ in deportations, and track in â€œnear real-timeâ€ which individuals leave the country voluntarily. Palantir won the contract without a competitive bidding process, with ICE citing an â€œurgent and compelling needâ€ and stating that â€œPalantir is the only source that can provide the required capabilities â€¦ without causing unacceptable delays.â€ ICE renewed the contract on Sept. 25, bringing its total value to about $60 million â€” a relatively small amount in the context of Palantirâ€™s$2.87 billion revenue in 2024.

In an internal communication to employees in the spring, Palantir presented the project as a â€œprototypeâ€ and said â€œlonger-term engagementsâ€ were â€œTBD,â€ [according to a copy obtained by 404 Media](https://www.404media.co/this-is-palantirs-justification-for-building-ices-master-database/). The company said it was â€œpursuing this effort because we believe it is critical to national security and that our software can make a meaningful difference in the safety of all involved in enforcement actions.â€

ICE and Palantir have declined to disclose how many people the system tracks, which agencies it pulls data from, and whether there are safeguards against mistaken identity or overcollection of surveillance data. Shyam Sankar, Palantirâ€™s chief technology officer, told the New York Times in [a recent interview](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/10/30/opinion/palantir-shyam-sankar-military.html) that Immigration OS tracked encounters at the border, asylum applications and applications for benefits. Immigration OS does not track information of U.S. citizens who are relatives of undocumented immigrants, Palantir said in an emailed statement.

ICE adopted Immigration OS as it rolled out a campaign to identify and detain what it calls the â€œWorst of the Worst.â€ The agency has cited cases of undocumented immigrants committing serious crimes as justification for broad deportation sweeps through cities such as Chicago, Charlotte and Portland, Oregon. ICE and Palantir declined to say whether Immigration OS played a role in helping compile ICEâ€™s â€œWorst of the Worstâ€ lists.

Trump said on Thanksgiving Day that he would â€œpermanently pauseâ€ migration from â€œThird World Countries,â€ broadly deport undocumented immigrants, and end all federal benefits and subsidies to noncitizens. That would mark an escalation of a campaign that federal judges have [repeatedly ruled](https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/08/29/trump-deportation-expedited-removal/) exceeds [the administrationâ€™s legal authority](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/09/11/federal-judge-curbs-dhs-force-against-journalists-la/), with one Chicago judge saying last month that the use of force involved [â€œshocks the conscience.â€](https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/11/06/judge-sharply-condemns-federal-use-force-chicago-immigration-operation/) DHS has decried the rulings as coming from â€œactivist judgesâ€ and said its actions have been lawful.

In [an interview with Wired](https://www.wired.com/story/alex-karp-goes-to-war-palantir-big-interview/) published in November, Karp said he had previously â€œpulled thingsâ€ that he believed were being deployed in violation of the companyâ€™s code of conduct, while rejecting contentions that its immigration software is. Asked whether he needed to take a closer look at how Palantirâ€™s products were being used in the United States, he called it â€œexactly the right question,â€ adding: â€œIâ€™m telling you that I have done this, and I will continue to do it.â€

Wendy R. Anderson, who was Palantirâ€™s senior vice president for national security until May, said Karp has never wavered in his conviction that tech companies working in defense have a duty to the country, not to politics.

â€œAlex starts from a single, nonnegotiable premise: America has to win,â€ she said, speaking generally and not in reference to Immigration OS. â€œNot in a partisan sense, but in the enduring one â€” the survival of the United States and the Western institutions that make free societies possible.â€

Palantir, founded by Karp and PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel in 2003 in the wake of 9/11, has long drawn criticism from civil rights activists over the powerful data management tools it sold to the likes of the Pentagon, CIA and ICE.

Karp â€” the son of a Jewish father and African American mother who took him to civil rights protests when he was a child â€” has long been outspoken in his self-identification as a Democrat and his beliefs in privacy protections. â€œWe as a company, and I as an individual, always have been deeply involved in supporting progressive values and causes,â€ Karp [said in 2011](https://www.businessinsider.com/palantir-wikileaks-apology-2011-2).

In summer 2015, shortly after Trump announced his first major presidential run, Karp told his staff that he had turned down an opportunity to meet Trump, as â€œit would be hard to make up someone I find less appealing,â€ according to [a leaked video published by BuzzFeed](https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/williamalden/video-shows-palantir-ceo-ridiculing-trump-and-slamming-his). Karp said he opposed Trumpâ€™s broad deportation platform, saying it made â€œno senseâ€ to throw out hardworking people. He said blaming immigrants for the nationâ€™s ills would bring up â€œthe worst that a society can bring up.â€

During Trumpâ€™s first presidency, Palantir said it would not work directly with ICEâ€™s Enforcement and Removal Operations arm on deportations, citing the risk of human rights violations. The company limited its contracts to the agencyâ€™s Homeland Security Investigations division, which worked on issues such as terrorism, sex trafficking and drug smuggling, though in practice [there was at least some crossover with raids on undocumented immigrants](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/08/22/war-inside-palantir-data-mining-firms-ties-ice-under-attack-by-employees/).

Palantir had made that distinction, Courtney Bowman, the companyâ€™s director of privacy and civil liberties, [wrote in a 2020 letter](https://www.business-humanrights.org/en/latest-news/letter-from-palantir-responding-to-amnesty-international/) to Amnesty International, â€œbecause we share your organizationâ€™s concern with the potential serious human rights violations against migrants, refugees, and asylum seekers at the U.S.-Mexico border and risks of disproportionate immigration enforcement inside the U.S.â€

Critics say Immigration OS represents a breach of those principles. The project has drawn public backlash, including from Y Combinator co-founder Paul Graham, who [wrote on X](https://x.com/paulg/status/1913338841068404903) that Palantir was â€œbuilding the infrastructure of the police state.â€ In a public letter, 13 of the companyâ€™s former employees accused Palantirâ€™s leadership of being â€œcomplicitâ€ in â€œnormalizing authoritarianismâ€ in America.

Within Palantir, executives defended the project by citing changing voter sentiment on the border issue and changes to ICEâ€™s structure. In one of his first executive orders in January, Trump had ordered ICEâ€™s Homeland Security Investigations to prioritize immigration enforcement instead of national security.

â€œThe national conversation around immigration enforcement, both at the border and in the interior of the United States has shifted,â€ the company wrote in the internal communication obtained by 404 Media. Palantir said it had realized that â€œto really support the agencyâ€™s immigration enforcement mission, we must expand our aperture â€¦ this means supporting workflows that are substantially distinct from our historical scope and into Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO).â€

The policy reversal prompted some employee resignations. Brianna Katherine Martin, who had been a U.S. government strategist at the company for almost three years, left in May, citing the recent expansion of the companyâ€™s work with ICE.

â€œFor most of my time here, I found the way that Palantir grappled with the weight of our capabilities to be refreshing, transparent, and conscionable,â€ Martin wrote on LinkedIn. â€œThis has changed for me over the past few months.â€ She did not respond to requests for comment.

The deepened partnership with ICE has come amid other changes at the company.

Palantir revised its employee code of conduct in March, removing pledges to avoid biased decision-making and eschew unfair action based on race or national origin. The â€œProtect the Vulnerableâ€ section of the code previously said: â€œWe will not create or perpetuate the unfair treatment and/or stigmatization of individuals or groups, particularly when such unfair action is based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity, disability, age, ancestry, marital status, citizenship, or sexual orientation.â€ The new version pledges more generally to avoid unfair action â€œbased on any characteristic protected by federal, state, or local laws.â€

Palantir also deleted a section that said employees should strive to overcome conscious and unconscious biases in their decision-making. The section now says employees should engage with one another with respect.

The code-of-conduct changes were made in response to Trump executive orders unrelated to the companyâ€™s ICE business, according to a person familiar with the matter, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the shift. Trump [had forbidden](https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/ending-illegal-discrimination-and-restoring-merit-based-opportunity/) federal contractors from â€œillegalâ€ diversity practices in January.

Karp biographer Michael Steinberger, whose book â€œThe Philosopher in the Valleyâ€ was published last month, said his interviews revealed Karpâ€™s increasing exasperation with what he saw as the Democratic Partyâ€™s unwillingness to control the border and preoccupation with identity politics.

â€œHe has definitely moved to the right,â€ Steinberger said. â€œThough I suspect he would be more inclined to say that he thinks the left left him.â€

An important factor in Karpâ€™s rightward shift has been the Oct. 7 attack on Israel two years ago**,** Steinberger wrote in his book. â€œIâ€™m now very willing to overlook my disagreements with Republicans on other issues because of the position they have taken on this one,â€ he quotes Karp as saying in the book.

In [a letter](https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/amr51/0211/2025/en/) in July to Amnesty International, responding to questions about its ICE contracts, Palantir said that although it took the human rights risks of its work with governments seriously, its role was to serve as a responsible federal contractor and uphold the law, not to set U.S. government policy.

â€œPalantir is not an oversight authority entrusted with scrutinizing or questioning executive branch actors,â€ the company wrote.

_Elizabeth Dwoskin, Douglas MacMillan, Gerrit De Vynck, Marianne LeVine and Aaron Schaffer contributed to this report._
